attributes.Title: Rsrch Issues in Envir Plan Des
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Sustainable Community
394RI
UMass Amherst
Survey of research issues in environmental design and planning. Designed to assist students in developing research in their area of interest. Includes selecting a topic for research, synthesizing the pertinent literature, developing research questions, designing a research study, and communicating the research findings verbally, visually, and in writing. This course satisfies the Integrative Experience requirement for BS-SUSTCOMM (formally BS-EnvDes) majors.
Open to junior and senior ENVIRDES or SUSTCOMM majors only.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
32848

attributes.Title: Global Cities & Global Issues
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Sustainable Community
125
UMass Amherst
Cities are dynamic organisms whose inhabitants require food, water, shelter, safety, commerce, leadership, and equity. For most people, the city can be a wonderful place to live in. For persons without privilege, the necessary goods and services that are require for a quality life may be lacking. In this course, students will note that every village, town, city, or mega-city has some type of challenge. By examining cities within a global context, students should recognize that any challenge can also be viewed as an opportunity for implementing positive change. As such, we examine global cities in order to ask a central question: what does it mean to be an active and engaged citizen living in any city, town, or village?
Open to Sophomores & Freshmen only.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
70313

attributes.Title: Ideas That Change the World
attributes.Description:
Spring
2015
Honors College
201
UMass Amherst
In this seminar, students will examine texts and works of art that have profoundly shaped the world we live in. The course is divided into four units: Models of Inquiry; the Impact of Science and Technology; Social Philosophy and Civic Engagement; and Art in the World. The course is supplemented with several plenary lectures by distinguished honors faculty speakers.
This course is open to Commonwealth Honors College students only.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
16389

attributes.Title: Plants In Landscape
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Sustainable Community
335
UMass Amherst
With lab. Introduction to 200 basic ornamental plants used in landscape architectural, horticultural, arboricultural, and other design uses; their identification, uses, and cultural requirements. Two weekly field trips around campus. Workbook with sketches required.
Multiple required components--lab and/or discussion section. To register, submit requests for all components simultaneously.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: Urban Policies
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Sustainable Community
577
UMass Amherst
Social, cultural, political, and economic analyses of urban policies and practices. Various disciplinary approaches used for critiquing and developing appropriate policies, including urban planning, anthropology, geography, political science, media studies, sociology, and economics. Includes service learning component.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: S-Roots&Branchesof20/21Century
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Sustainable Community
591A
UMass Amherst
Building on the spatial history of landscape design & planning this course explores the roots and branches of contemporary works to advance your understanding of landscape garden places and to spark your future practice in environmental design as a more sustainable and beautiful landscape.
Open to Graduate students only.
Varies from 1 to 4 credits
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
70721

attributes.Title: ST-Intro/Community Engagement
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Sustainable Community
195C
UMass Amherst
To imagine changing even a small part of the world is a daunting, yet exhilarating proposition.  Through class exercises, readings, exploration of social policy, guest speakers and a project that takes you to parts of the campus you might otherwise not explore, you will acquire knowledge and skills necessary for becoming a person who can make a difference.  By the end of the semester you will have learned to connect ideas with action, have made a positive contribution to your community, and understand, through experience, the personal and social value of community engagement.  This is a foundation course for the Civic Engagement and Service Learning certificate.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: Dynamics of Human Habitation
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Sustainable Community
205
UMass Amherst
How the built environment is shaped by humans. The forces that go into developing human settlements, how these environments change, how different groups experience the environment, and how enviromental designers work within this context.  (Gen.Ed. I, U)
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: ST-Computers In Envir Design
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Sustainable Community
597A
UMass Amherst
Introduction to the range of computer applications available for the environmental design professions. Site analysis techniques, computer aided design, and methods of data management on the computer.
This course is open to SUSTCOMM (Sustainable Community Development, formerly  ENVIRDES) and LANDARCH (Landscape Architecture) majors only.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
62851

attributes.Title: FYS -FromGroundUp:PlanBuild
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Sustainable Community
191SUST1
UMass Amherst
Open to first-year SBS students (include direct admits to all SBS majors and Exploratory Track SBS students)   This course will introduce students to areas of study related to Landscape Architecture and Regional Planning:  the social, aesthetic, community and environmental perspectives on sustainability within the fields of planning and design.  In addition, the course will help new students to define a pathway in their careers as UMass students in the College of Social & Behavioral Sciences.  They will become familiar with SBS basics, personal and academic skills, and the available resources at the University.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
40678

attributes.Title: Awareness of the Visual Envir.
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Sustainable Community
140
UMass Amherst
Examines physical elements that compose a variety of visual environments including gardens and paintings; the cultural values underlying different types of American landscapes, from wilderness to cities; and the ways in which other cultures perceive, use, and create their own visual environments.  (Gen.Ed. AT)
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Sustainable Community
592D

This seminar is about understanding and evaluating the quality of the urban environment, emphasizing the role that streets, neighborhoods and commercial districts play in creating attractive, successful places.  Through classroom discussions, readings and site visits, students will discover the ingredients that make good urban spaces, and the role that designers play in creating them.
